author: Rick Deakin

comments.message: I certainly agree it was scary to see how randomly they acted. Sheriff told his deputy to go to the clinic. Terrible idea.Get a quarantine order signed - how? By going in the house!

Maybe something similar that's already been done if you don't have an original one? If you need inspiration on getting visual, check out our guide here - http://ideo.pn/vis-uals.

description:
I think goverments would probably welcome a WHO response sheet, with probably 3 levels of response (one for 'gold standard' western health care facilities with blood testing labs on site, and the other 2 tailored to countries with less and less resources) including immediate removal of potential patients from triage area to a quarantine area (surely having an ebola victim in a room with other people with compromised immune systems, coughing and sneezing, is asking for an epidemic?) instructions for clean-up of patients' living quarters, investigating and testing known contacts, etc.
So its really just a 'best practice' brief that can be universally adopted, rather than allowing heath care chiefs or bureaucrats to make a well intentioned but untimately poor choice in response at any level.
summary: the random and inconsistent response of the Texas health care system to the patient who came to Dallas with symptoms of Ebola is likely to be played out in many countries in Europe, Asia and the Americas that find themselves with patients (And this is a premier health care system, with millions of dollars in resources, rather than an impoverished health care system in a low GDP country).Rather than work out a response system (isolation, environment scrub-down, list of contacts made in symptomatic time period, etc) based on trial and error, all health care authorities hand down one set of "if...then" instructions, via their government (why risk individual state interpretations), posted in all hospitals and care centers.
title: one comprehensive response plan, drafted by the WHO, to be approved by each government, and enacted (at achievable levels of response) by each country/state/province that has a patient complain of symptoms.
